articles.title: MÃ¸te din tyske partners familie: Essensielle fraser for Ã¥ gjÃ¸re et godt inntrykk
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Endelig skal du mÃ¸te din tyske partners familie! Dette er et stort steg i forholdet deres, men vi vet det kan fÃ¸les litt skummelt. Ikke bekymre deg - med de rette tyske setningene og litt kulturell forstÃ¥else kommer du til Ã¥ gjÃ¸re en fantastisk fÃ¸rsteinntrykk. La oss gjÃ¸re dette Ã¸yeblikket spesielt sammen!

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ich freue mich, Sie kennenzulernen"
  translation="Jeg gleder meg til Ã¥ bli kjent med deg"
  pronunciation="ikh FROY-eh mikh zee KEN-en-tsu-lehr-en"
  context="Den perfekte Ã¥pningsreplikken nÃ¥r du mÃ¸ter foreldrene for fÃ¸rste gang"
/>

## FÃ¸r du gÃ¥r: Forberedelse gjÃ¸r mester

Ã… mÃ¸te din partners familie i Tyskland kommer med noen spesielle forventninger. Tyskere verdser hÃ¸flighet, direkte kommunikasjon og Ã¦rlighet. Hvis du vil lÃ¦re mer grunnleggende tysk fÃ¸rst, sjekk ut [essensielle tyske fraser for par](/learn/no/de/essential-german-phrases-for-couples/).

<VocabCard
  word="die Familie"
  translation="familien"
  pronunciation="dee fah-MEE-lee-eh"
  example="Deine Familie ist sehr nett (Din familie er veldig hyggelig)"
/>

<CultureTip flag="ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª" title="HÃ¥ndtrykk vs klem">
I Tyskland er hÃ¥ndtrykk standard nÃ¥r du hilser, selv med familiemedlemmer du aldri har mÃ¸tt. Vent til noen inviterer til klem - tyskere er generelt mer reserverte med fysisk kontakt ved fÃ¸rste mÃ¸te.
</CultureTip>

## Essential fraser for fÃ¸rste mÃ¸te

| Tysk | Uttale | Norsk | NÃ¥r Ã¥ bruke |
|------|---------|-------|-------------|
| **Guten Tag** | GOO-ten tahk | God dag | Formell hilsen (dagtid) |
| **Hallo** | HAH-loh | Hei | Uformell hilsen |
| **Wie geht es Ihnen?** | vee gate ess EE-nen | Hvordan stÃ¥r det til? | Formelt (til foreldre) |
| **Wie geht's?** | vee gates | Hvordan gÃ¥r det? | Uformelt (til sÃ¸sken/jevnaldrende) |
| **Freut mich** | FROYt mikh | Hyggelig Ã¥ mÃ¸te deg | Kort og hÃ¸flig |
| **Bitte schÃ¶n** | BIT-te shurn | VÃ¦r sÃ¥ god | NÃ¥r du fÃ¥r noe |
| **Danke schÃ¶n** | DAHN-ke shurn | Takk skal du ha | Standard takk |
| **Entschuldigung** | ent-SHOOL-dee-goong | Unnskyld | Unnskyld/be om oppmerksomhet |
| **Tut mir leid** | toot meer leed | Beklager | Unnskyld/for Ã¥ si ifra |
| **Kein Problem** | kine proh-BLEHM | Ikke noe problem | Svar pÃ¥ takk/unnskyld |

## Vanlige scenarioer og hva du kan forvente deg

### Ankomst til huset
NÃ¥r du ankommer, vil noen vanligvis Ã¥pne dÃ¸ren og invitere deg inn:

**Vert:** *â€žKommen Sie herein!â€œ* (KOH-men zee hehr-EEN - Kom inn!)
**Deg:** *â€žVielen Dankâ€œ* (FEE-len dahnk - Tusen takk)

Ta av deg skoene hvis du ser at andre gjÃ¸r det, eller spÃ¸r: *â€žSoll ich die Schuhe ausziehen?â€œ* (zoll ikh dee SHOO-eh OWS-tsee-en - Skal jeg ta av skoene?)

### Rundt middagsbordet
Tyske familier verdsetter mÃ¥ltidet som samlingspunkt. Her er noen nÃ¸kkelsetninger:

<VocabCard
  word="Guten Appetit"
  translation="Velbekomme"
  pronunciation="GOO-ten ah-peh-TEET"
  example="FÃ¸r mÃ¥ltidet sier alle dette sammen"
/>

| Tysk | Uttale | Norsk | Bruk |
|------|---------|-------|-------|
| **KÃ¶nnen Sie das bitte wiederholen?** | KOHN-en zee dahs BIT-te VEE-der-hoh-len | Kan du gjenta det? | Hvis du ikke hÃ¸rte |
| **Das schmeckt sehr gut** | dahs shmeckt zeyr goot | Dette smaker veldig godt | Kompliment til kokken |
| **Ich bin satt** | ikh bin saht | Jeg er mett | NÃ¥r du er ferdig |
| **Darf ich noch etwas haben?** | dahrf ikh nokh ET-vahs HAH-ben | Kan jeg fÃ¥ litt mer? | Politt Ã¥ be om pÃ¥fyll |

### Samtaleemner og spÃ¸rsmÃ¥l
VÃ¦r forberedt pÃ¥ personlige spÃ¸rsmÃ¥l - tyskere er direkte! De spÃ¸r gjerne om jobb, familie og planer. Hvis du vil imponere med romantiske setninger, sjekk [romantiske tyske fraser for enhver anledning](/learn/no/de/romantic-german-phrases-for-every-occasion/).

**Vanlige spÃ¸rsmÃ¥l du kan fÃ¥:**
- *â€žWoher kommen Sie?â€œ* (VOH-her KOH-men zee - Hvor kommer du fra?)
- *â€žWas arbeiten Sie?â€œ* (vahs AHR-bite-en zee - Hva jobber du med?)
- *â€žWie haben Sie sich kennengelernt?â€œ* (vee HAH-ben zee zikh KEN-en-geh-lehrt - Hvordan mÃ¸ttes dere?)

## Vokabularliste: Familie og relasjoner

| Tysk | Norsk | Uttale |
|------|-------|---------|
| **die Mutter** | mor | MOO-ter |
| **der Vater** | far | FAH-ter |
| **die Schwester** | sÃ¸ster | SHVES-ter |
| **der Bruder** | bror | BROO-der |
| **die GroÃŸmutter** | bestemor | GROHS-moot-er |
| **der GroÃŸvater** | bestefar | GROHS-fah-ter |
| **der Onkel** | onkel | ONG-kel |
| **die Tante** | tante | TAHN-teh |
| **die Cousine** | kusine | koo-ZEE-neh |
| **der Cousin** | fetter | koo-ZANG |
| **die Tochter** | datter | TOKH-ter |
| **der Sohn** | sÃ¸nn | zohn |
| **die Eltern** | foreldre | ELL-tern |
| **die Geschwister** | sÃ¸sken | geh-SHVIS-ter |

## HÃ¸flige fraser og formaliteter

I Tyskland er det viktig Ã¥ bruke riktig hÃ¸flighetsnivÃ¥. Bruk **Sie**-formen med foreldre og voksne du ikke kjenner:

**Formelle setninger:**
- *â€žDarf ich Ihnen helfen?â€œ* (dahrf ikh EE-nen HELF-en - Kan jeg hjelpe deg?)
- *â€žWÃ¼rden Sie mir bitte...â€œ* (VOOR-den zee meer BIT-te - Ville du vÃ¦re sÃ¥ snill Ã¥...)

**Uformelle setninger** (til sÃ¸sken og jevnaldrende):
- *â€žKann ich dir helfen?â€œ* (kahn ikh deer HELF-en - Kan jeg hjelpe deg?)
- *â€žMagst du...â€œ* (mahkst doo - Har du lyst til...)

<CultureTip flag="ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª" title="Ã˜yekontakt ved skÃ¥l">
NÃ¥r noen sier â€žProstâ€œ eller â€žZum Wohlâ€œ (skÃ¥l), er det viktig Ã¥ se dem i Ã¸ynene mens dere klinker. Ã… ikke gjÃ¸re dette anses som uflaks!
</CultureTip>

## Hvis ting gÃ¥r galt...

Ikke panikk! Her er setninger for Ã¥ redde situasjonen:

| Tysk | Uttale | Norsk |
|------|---------|-------|
| **Ich verstehe nicht** | ikh fer-SHTE-eh nikht | Jeg forstÃ¥r ikke |
| **KÃ¶nnen Sie langsamer sprechen?** | KOHN-en zee LAHNG-zah-mer shprekh-en | Kan du snakke saktere? |
| **Wie sagt man das auf Deutsch?** | vee zahkt mahn dahs owf doych | Hvordan sier man det pÃ¥ tysk? |
| **Ich lerne noch Deutsch** | ikh LER-neh nokh doych | Jeg lÃ¦rer fortsatt tysk |
| **Tut mir leid, ich bin nervÃ¶s** | toot meer leed ikh bin ner-VOHS | Beklager, jeg er nervÃ¸s |
| **KÃ¶nnen Sie mir helfen?** | KOHN-en zee meer HELF-en | Kan du hjelpe meg? |

## Pro-tips fra vÃ¥re tyske eksperter

1. **Ta med en liten gave** - Blomster til vertsinnen eller en flaske vin er alltid populÃ¦rt
2. **VÃ¦r presis** - Tyskere verdsetter punktlighet. Helst 5 minutter fÃ¸r avtalt tid
3. **Komplimenter maten** - Tyske husmÃ¸dre og fedre er stolte av maten sin
4. **Vis interesse** - SpÃ¸r om familiemedlemmer, huset eller hobbyer
5. **Ikke vÃ¦r redd for taushet** - Tyskere er komfortable med stillhet i samtaler
6. **VÃ¦r Ã¦rlig om tysken din** - De vil sette pris pÃ¥ at du prÃ¸ver!

<VocabCard
  word="die Einladung"
  translation="invitasjonen"
  pronunciation="dine EYN-lah-doong"
  example="Vielen Dank fÃ¼r die Einladung (Tusen takk for invitasjonen)"
/>

<CultureTip flag="ðŸ‡©ðŸ‡ª" title="Sko-spÃ¸rringen">
Mange tyske husholdninger har regler om sko innendÃ¸rs. Se etter skohyller ved inngangen eller spÃ¸r hÃ¸flig: 'Soll ich die Schuhe ausziehen?' Det viser respekt for hjemmet deres.
</CultureTip>

## Rask referanse-kort (ta skjermbilde!)

1. **Ich freue mich, Sie kennenzulernen** - Hyggelig Ã¥ mÃ¸te deg
2. **Danke, dass ich hier sein darf** - Takk for at jeg fÃ¥r vÃ¦re her
3. **Das Essen schmeckt wunderbar** - Maten smaker nydelig
4. **Ihre Familie ist sehr nett** - Din familie er veldig hyggelig
5. **KÃ¶nnen Sie das bitte wiederholen?** - Kan du gjenta?
6. **Ich lerne noch Deutsch** - Jeg lÃ¦rer fortsatt tysk
7. **Darf ich Ihnen helfen?** - Kan jeg hjelpe?
8. **Vielen Dank fÃ¼r alles** - Takk for alt
9. **Auf Wiedersehen** - Ha det bra
10. **Es war sehr schÃ¶n** - Det var veldig hyggelig

Din tyske familie vil bli imponert over innsatsen du legger ned! Husk at det viktigste er Ã¥ vÃ¦re deg selv og vise ekte interesse for dem og kulturen deres. Lykke til med dette spennende mÃ¸tet!

<CTA />

articles.title: Wymowa holenderska - przewodnik dla PolakÃ³w
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Holenderska wymowa moze byc wyzwaniem dla PolakÃ³w! Szczegolnie gloski gardlowe i specyficzne samogloski. Ten przewodnik pomoze ci opanowac podstawy.

## Najtrudniejsze dzwieki

<PhraseOfDay
  word="G"
  translation="Dzwiek gardlowy"
  pronunciation="jak chrzakniecie"
  context="Najbardziej charakterystyczny dzwiek holenderskiego"
/>

### Gardlowe "G" i "CH"

To najbardziej rozpoznawalny dzwiek holenderskiego - przypomina polskie "ch", ale bardziej gardlowe.

| Slowo | Wymowa | Znaczenie |
|-------|--------|-----------|
| **goed** | chut | dobry |
| **gezellig** | che-ze-lich | przytulny |
| **nacht** | nacht | noc |
| **lachen** | la-chen | smiac siÄ™ |
| **echt** | echt | naprawde |

<CultureTip title="Regionalne rÃ³Å¼nice" flag="ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡±">
"G" brzmi inaczej w roznych regionach! Na polnocy jest bardziej miekkie, na poludniu bardziej gardlowe. Oba warianty sÄ… poprawne!
</CultureTip>

## Samogloski holenderskie

### Krotkie samogloski

| Litera | Wymowa | Przyklad | Znaczenie |
|--------|--------|----------|-----------|
| **a** | a (krÃ³tkie) | **man** | mezczyzna |
| **e** | e (krÃ³tkie) | **bed** | lozko |
| **i** | i (krÃ³tkie) | **dit** | to |
| **o** | o (krÃ³tkie) | **bos** | las |
| **u** | u (zamkniete) | **bus** | autobus |

### Dlugie samogloski

<VocabCard
  word="Dlugie samogloski"
  translation="Pisane podwojnie lub z jedna spolglaoska"
  pronunciation="aa, ee, oo, uu"
  example="Maan (ksiezyc), been (noga), boom (drzewo)"
/>

| Litera | Wymowa | Przyklad | Znaczenie |
|--------|--------|----------|-----------|
| **aa/a** | a: (dÅ‚ugie) | **maan/manen** | ksiezyc/ksiezyce |
| **ee/e** | e: (dÅ‚ugie) | **been/benen** | noga/nogi |
| **oo/o** | o: (dÅ‚ugie) | **boom/bomen** | drzewo/drzewa |
| **uu/u** | y: (jak niem. u) | **muur/muren** | mur/mury |

## Dyftongi (polaczenia samoglosek)

<PhraseOfDay
  word="UI"
  translation="Trudny dzwiek!"
  pronunciation="aj-u (szybko)"
  context="Najtrudniejszy holenderski dyftong"
/>

| Dyftong | Wymowa | Przyklad | Znaczenie |
|---------|--------|----------|-----------|
| **ei/ij** | aj | **wijn, trein** | wino, pociag |
| **ou/au** | aÅ‚ | **hout, blauw** | drewno, niebieski |
| **ui** | aj-u | **huis, buiten** | dom, na zewnatrz |
| **eu** | e-u | **neus, deur** | nos, drzwi |
| **oe** | u | **goed, boek** | dobry, ksiazka |
| **ie** | i | **niet, lief** | nie, mily |

<CultureTip title="UI - wyzwanie" flag="ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡±">
Dzwiek "ui" jest najtrudniejszy dla obcokrajowcow! Wyobraz sobie, Å¼e mowisz "aj" i "u" jednoczesnie. Potrzeba praktyki!
</CultureTip>

## Spolgloski

### Podobne do polskich

| Litera | Wymowa | Jak w polskim |
|--------|--------|---------------|
| **b** | b | b |
| **d** | d | d |
| **f** | f | f |
| **k** | k | k |
| **l** | l | l |
| **m** | m | m |
| **n** | n | n |
| **p** | p | p |
| **s** | s | s |
| **t** | t | t |
| **z** | z | z |

### Inne niz polskie

<VocabCard
  word="W"
  translation="Miedzy W a F"
  pronunciation="w (z ustami jak do f)"
  example="Water (woda), wijn (wino), weg (droga)"
/>

| Litera | Wymowa | Przyklad | Znaczenie |
|--------|--------|----------|-----------|
| **w** | w/v | **water** | woda |
| **v** | v (delikatne) | **vader** | ojciec |
| **j** | j | **ja** | tak |
| **r** | r (gardlowe) | **rood** | czerwony |
| **sch** | sch | **school** | szkola |

## Koncowki wyrazow

### Koncowka "-en"

<VocabCard
  word="-en"
  translation="Wymawiane jako schwa"
  pronunciation="e (zredukowane)"
  example="Eten, lopen, praten - jedzenie, chodzenie, rozmowa"
/>

W holenderskim koncowka "-en" brzmi prawie jak samo "e"!

| Slowo | Wymowa | Znaczenie |
|-------|--------|-----------|
| **eten** | e-te | jesc |
| **lopen** | lo-pe | chodzic |
| **praten** | pra-te | mowic |
| **slapen** | sla-pe | spac |

### UbezdÅºwiÄ™cznienie

Na koncu wyrazu dzwiÄ™czne spolgloski staja siÄ™ bezdÅºwiÄ™czne:

| Pisownia | Wymowa | Znaczenie |
|----------|--------|-----------|
| **bed** | bet | lozko |
| **rood** | rot | czerwony |
| **rib** | rip | zebro |
| **hond** | hont | pies |

## Akcent

<CultureTip title="Gdzie akcent?" flag="ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡±">
W holenderskim akcent zwykle pada na pierwsza sylabe. Wyjatki to sÅ‚owa z przedrostkami be-, ge-, ver-, ont- i sÅ‚owa zapozyczone.
</CultureTip>

| Slowo | Akcent | Znaczenie |
|-------|--------|-----------|
| **'water** | pierwsza sylaba | woda |
| **'eten** | pierwsza sylaba | jesc |
| **be'talen** | druga sylaba | placic |
| **ver'staan** | druga sylaba | rozumiec |

## Ä†wiczenia wymowy

### Cwiczenie 1: Gardlowe G

Powtarzaj:
- Goed, goed, goed
- Gezellig, gezellig
- Dag, dag, dag

### Cwiczenie 2: Dyftongi

Powtarzaj pary:
- huis - hous (dom - trzymaj)
- wijn - waan (wino - uÅ‚uda)
- buit - bout (Å‚up - Å›ruba)

### Cwiczenie 3: Romantyczne sÅ‚owa

<VocabCard
  word="Ik hou van je"
  translation="Kocham cie"
  pronunciation="ik haÅ‚ fan je"
  example="Cwicz to zdanie codzieÅ„nie!"
/>

Powtarzaj romantyczne zwroty:
- Ik hou van je
- Je bent mooi
- Schat, kom hier

## Typowe bledy PolakÃ³w

| Blad | Poprawnie | Wskazowka |
|------|-----------|-----------|
| Twarde "g" | Miekkie gardlowe "g" | Wyobraz sobie chrzakniecie |
| "ui" jako "uj" | "ui" jako aj-u | Polacz aj i u |
| Wyrazne "-en" | Zredukowane "-en" | Prawie samo "e" |
| Polskie "r" | Gardlowe "r" | R z tylu gardla |

## Porownanie z polskim

<CultureTip title="Zalety" flag="ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡±">
Polacy maja przewage - znamy wiele spolglosek podobnych do holenderskich. Najtrudniejsze to gardlowe dzwieki i specyficzne dyftongi.
</CultureTip>

| Aspekt | Polski | Holenderski |
|--------|--------|-------------|
| Gardlowe G | Nie ma | Bardzo waÅ¼ne |
| Dyftongi | Malo | Bardzo wiele |
| Koncowki | Wyrazne | Zredukowane |
| Akcent | Przedostatnia sylaba | Zwykle pierwsza |

## Podsumowanie

Holenderska wymowa wymaga praktyki, szczegÃ³lnie gardlowe "g" i dyftongi. Nie zrazaj siÄ™ - z czasem stanie siÄ™ naturalna!

## Kontynuuj nauke

- **[Podstawy gramatyki](/learn/pl/nl/dutch-grammar-basics/)** - Gramatyka holenderska
- **[Jak powiedziec kocham cie](/learn/pl/nl/how-to-say-i-love-you-in-dutch/)** - Cwicz romantyczne zwroty
- **[Holenderskie zdrobnienia](/learn/pl/nl/dutch-pet-names-terms-of-endearment/)** - Czule slowka
- **[Czy holenderski jest trudny?](/learn/pl/nl/is-dutch-hard-to-learn/)** - Ocena trudnoÅ›Ä‡i

<CTA text="Gotowi doskonalic wymowe?" buttonText="Zacznij teraz" />

articles.title: Spanish Negation: Saying No with Confidence
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Saying "no" is a fundamental part of any language, and in Spanish, negation has some interesting rules that differ from English. Whether you're politely declining an invitation, expressing that you don't understand, or playfully saying "I'll never let you go," mastering Spanish negation will make your conversations more complete and natural.

Learning negation together as a couple gives you the tools to express boundaries, preferences, and even romantic promises like "I'll never stop loving you!"

## The Basics: Simple Negation with "No"

The simplest way to make a sentence negative in Spanish is to place **"no"** directly before the verb:

| Affirmative | Negative |
|-------------|----------|
| Hablo espaÃ±ol | No hablo espaÃ±ol |
| Entiendo | No entiendo |
| Me gusta | No me gusta |
| Quiero ir | No quiero ir |

<VocabCard
  word="no"
  translation="no / not"
  pronunciation="[noh]"
  example="No te preocupes, todo estarÃ¡ bien."
/>

### Position of "No"

"No" always comes immediately before the verb (or before object pronouns that precede the verb):

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No te amo | I don't love you |
| No me gusta eso | I don't like that |
| No lo sÃ© | I don't know (it) |
| No puedo ir | I can't go |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="No te preocupes"
  translation="Don't worry"
  pronunciation="[noh teh preh-oh-KOO-pehs]"
  context="A comforting phrase to reassure your partner"
/>

## Negative Words in Spanish

Spanish has a rich set of negative words that work together with (or replace) "no":

| Negative Word | Meaning | Opposite |
|---------------|---------|----------|
| no | no, not | sÃ­ |
| nunca | never | siempre |
| jamÃ¡s | never (emphatic) | siempre |
| nada | nothing | todo/algo |
| nadie | nobody | todos/alguien |
| ninguno/a | none, not any | alguno/a |
| tampoco | neither, not either | tambiÃ©n |
| ni... ni | neither... nor | o... o |

<VocabCard
  word="nunca"
  translation="never"
  pronunciation="[NOON-kah]"
  example="Nunca te olvidarÃ©."
/>

## Double Negatives: A Spanish Feature

Unlike English, Spanish uses **double negatives** - and they're not just acceptable, they're required! When a negative word follows the verb, "no" must come before the verb:

| Spanish (correct) | English |
|-------------------|---------|
| No tengo nada | I don't have anything |
| No veo a nadie | I don't see anyone |
| No voy nunca | I never go |
| No quiero tampoco | I don't want it either |

<CultureTip title="Double Negatives are Correct!" flag="ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸">
In English, double negatives are considered incorrect ("I don't have nothing"). In Spanish, they're grammatically required when the negative word comes after the verb. This is one case where two negatives don't make a positive - they reinforce the negation!
</CultureTip>

### Single Negative (When Negative Word Comes First)

When the negative word comes BEFORE the verb, you don't need "no":

| Before Verb | After Verb |
|-------------|------------|
| Nunca como carne | No como carne nunca |
| Nadie vino | No vino nadie |
| Nada pasÃ³ | No pasÃ³ nada |

Both forms are correct and have the same meaning.

## Deep Dive: Each Negative Word

### Nunca / JamÃ¡s (Never)

"Nunca" and "jamÃ¡s" both mean "never," but "jamÃ¡s" is more emphatic:

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Nunca te dejarÃ© | I'll never leave you |
| JamÃ¡s te mentirÃ© | I'll never (ever) lie to you |
| No me rindo nunca | I never give up |
| Nunca jamÃ¡s | Never ever |

<VocabCard
  word="jamÃ¡s"
  translation="never (emphatic)"
  pronunciation="[hah-MAHS]"
  example="JamÃ¡s me cansarÃ© de ti."
/>

### Nada (Nothing)

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No quiero nada | I don't want anything |
| Nada es imposible | Nothing is impossible |
| No pasÃ³ nada | Nothing happened |
| De nada | You're welcome (lit. "of nothing") |

**Common expressions:**
- "Nada mÃ¡s" = Nothing else / Just
- "Para nada" = Not at all
- "Nada de eso" = None of that

### Nadie (Nobody)

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No conozco a nadie | I don't know anyone |
| Nadie me entiende como tÃº | Nobody understands me like you |
| No hay nadie aquÃ­ | There's nobody here |
| A nadie le importa | Nobody cares |

<VocabCard
  word="nadie"
  translation="nobody / no one"
  pronunciation="[NAH-dee-eh]"
  example="Nadie te amarÃ¡ como yo."
/>

### Ninguno/a (None, Not any)

"Ninguno" changes form based on gender and shortens before masculine singular nouns:

| Form | Usage | Example |
|------|-------|---------|
| ninguno | masculine | No tengo ninguno |
| ningÃºn | before masc. noun | NingÃºn problema |
| ninguna | feminine | Ninguna persona |

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No tengo ningÃºn problema | I don't have any problem |
| Ninguna idea es mala | No idea is bad |
| No hay ninguna razÃ³n | There's no reason |

### Tampoco (Neither, Not Either)

"Tampoco" is the negative counterpart of "tambiÃ©n" (also):

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| - No me gusta el cafÃ©. | - I don't like coffee. |
| - A mÃ­ tampoco. | - Me neither. |
| Yo no voy. Ella tampoco. | I'm not going. She isn't either. |
| No quiero ir tampoco | I don't want to go either |

<VocabCard
  word="tampoco"
  translation="neither / not either"
  pronunciation="[tahm-POH-koh]"
  example="- No tengo hambre. - Yo tampoco."
/>

### Ni... Ni (Neither... Nor)

Use "ni" to connect two negative elements:

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No quiero ni cafÃ© ni tÃ© | I want neither coffee nor tea |
| Ni tÃº ni yo | Neither you nor I |
| No tengo ni idea | I have no idea |
| Ni siquiera | Not even |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Ni tÃº ni nadie puede cambiar mi amor por ti"
  translation="Neither you nor anyone can change my love for you"
  pronunciation="[nee too nee NAH-dee-eh PWEH-deh kahm-bee-AHR mee ah-MOR por tee]"
  context="A passionate declaration of unwavering love"
/>

## Romantic Negative Phrases

### Promises of Forever

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Nunca te abandonarÃ© | I'll never abandon you |
| JamÃ¡s dejarÃ© de amarte | I'll never stop loving you |
| Nada ni nadie nos separarÃ¡ | Nothing and no one will separate us |
| No hay nadie como tÃº | There's nobody like you |
| Sin ti no soy nada | Without you, I'm nothing |

### Expressing Loyalty

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| No quiero a nadie mÃ¡s que a ti | I don't want anyone but you |
| Nunca te mentirÃ© | I'll never lie to you |
| No te cambiarÃ­a por nada | I wouldn't trade you for anything |
| JamÃ¡s me arrepentirÃ© de amarte | I'll never regret loving you |

<VocabCard
  word="sin ti"
  translation="without you"
  pronunciation="[seen tee]"
  example="Sin ti, mi vida no tiene sentido."
/>

## Negative Commands

When giving negative commands, "no" comes before the verb (in subjunctive form):

| Positive Command | Negative Command |
|-----------------|------------------|
| Â¡Habla! (Speak!) | Â¡No hables! (Don't speak!) |
| Â¡Come! (Eat!) | Â¡No comas! (Don't eat!) |
| Â¡Ven! (Come!) | Â¡No vengas! (Don't come!) |
| Â¡Ve! (Go!) | Â¡No vayas! (Don't go!) |

### Romantic Negative Commands

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Â¡No te vayas! | Don't go! |
| Â¡No me dejes! | Don't leave me! |
| Â¡No me olvides! | Don't forget me! |
| Â¡No te preocupes! | Don't worry! |
| Â¡No llores! | Don't cry! |

<CultureTip title="Softening Negatives" flag="ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸">
In Spanish-speaking cultures, negative responses are often softened with additional phrases. Instead of just "No," people might say "No, gracias" (No, thank you) or "No, pero gracias por preguntar" (No, but thanks for asking). This shows politeness while being clear.
</CultureTip>

## Answering Questions Negatively

### Polite Negative Responses

| Question | Polite Negative Response |
|----------|-------------------------|
| Â¿Quieres mÃ¡s? | No, gracias, estoy bien |
| Â¿Vienes a la fiesta? | No, lo siento, no puedo |
| Â¿Te gusta? | No mucho, pero gracias |
| Â¿Entiendes? | No del todo |

### Complete Negative Answers

When answering questions, Spanish often uses double negatives:

- "Â¿Tienes algo?" â†’ "No, no tengo nada"
- "Â¿Ves a alguien?" â†’ "No, no veo a nadie"
- "Â¿Vas alguna vez?" â†’ "No, no voy nunca"

## Practice Exercises for Couples

### Exercise 1: Transform to Negative

Make these sentences negative:

1. "Tengo hambre" â†’ "No tengo hambre"
2. "Quiero ir al cine" â†’ "No quiero ir al cine"
3. "Siempre llego tarde" â†’ "Nunca llego tarde" / "No llego tarde nunca"
4. "Alguien llamÃ³" â†’ "Nadie llamÃ³" / "No llamÃ³ nadie"

### Exercise 2: Respond Negatively

Answer these questions in the negative:

1. "Â¿Tienes algo para mÃ­?" â†’ "No, no tengo nada para ti"
2. "Â¿Conoces a alguien aquÃ­?" â†’ "No, no conozco a nadie aquÃ­"
3. "Â¿Vas al gimnasio a veces?" â†’ "No, no voy nunca al gimnasio"

### Exercise 3: Romantic Promises

Take turns making romantic promises using negative words:

- "Nunca te mentirÃ©"
- "JamÃ¡s dejarÃ© de quererte"
- "Nada me importa mÃ¡s que tÃº"
- "Nadie me conoce como tÃº"

<VocabCard
  word="Nunca me cansarÃ© de ti"
  translation="I'll never get tired of you"
  pronunciation="[NOON-kah meh kahn-sah-REH deh tee]"
  example="Por mÃ¡s tiempo que pase, nunca me cansarÃ© de ti."
/>

## Common Mistakes to Avoid

### Mistake 1: Forgetting Double Negatives
**Wrong:** "No tengo algo"
**Correct:** "No tengo nada"

### Mistake 2: Using "No" with Negative Words Before Verbs
**Wrong:** "No nunca voy" (redundant)
**Correct:** "Nunca voy" or "No voy nunca"

### Mistake 3: Forgetting "a" Before "nadie" as Object
**Wrong:** "No veo nadie"
**Correct:** "No veo a nadie"

## Expressing Negation Naturally

The key to natural Spanish negation is practice. Start with simple "no" sentences, then gradually incorporate other negative words. Before you know it, double negatives will feel completely natural!

Remember, learning to say "no" clearly and kindly is an important communication skill in any relationship. In Spanish, you now have a rich vocabulary to express everything from gentle refusals to passionate promises of "never letting go."

<CTA text="Ready to master Spanish negation together?" buttonText="Start Learning Now" />

articles.title: Spotkanie z rumunska rodzina partnera - przewodnik jÄ™zykowy
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Spotkanie z rodzina partnera to waÅ¼ny krok w kaÅ¼dym zwiazku. Rumunska rodzina jest bardzo zjednoczona i goscinnosc jest bardzo ceniona. Ten przewodnik przygotuje cie na to waÅ¼ne spotkanie!

## Nazwy czlonkow rodziny

<VocabCard
  word="familia"
  translation="rodzina"
  pronunciation="fa-MI-li-a"
  example="MÄƒ bucur sÄƒ cunosc familia ta."
/>

### Rodzice partnera

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **mamÄƒ / mÄƒmicÄƒ** | ma-ma / ma-mi-ka | mama / mamusia |
| **tatÄƒ / tÄƒtic** | ta-ta / ta-tik | tata / tatusio |
| **soacrÄƒ** | so-a-kra | tesciowa |
| **socru** | so-kru | tesc |
| **pÄƒrinÈ›i** | pa-rintsi | rodzice |

<CultureTip title="Formy zwracania sie" flag="ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡´">
Na poczatku zwracaj siÄ™ do rodzicow partnera per "dumneavoastrÄƒ" (Pan/Pani). Poczekaj, az sami zaproponuja przejscie na "tu". Mozesz tez uzywac "doamnÄƒ" (pani) i "domnule" (panie).
</CultureTip>

### Rodzenstwo i krewni

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **frate** | fra-te | brat |
| **sorÄƒ** | so-ra | siostra |
| **bunic / bunicul** | bu-nik / bu-ni-kul | dziadek |
| **bunicÄƒ / bunica** | bu-ni-ka / bu-ni-ka | babcia |
| **bunici** | bu-nitshi | dziadkowie |

### Dalsza rodzina

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **mÄƒtuÈ™Äƒ** | ma-tu-sha | ciotka |
| **unchi** | un-ki | wujek |
| **vÄƒr / veriÈ™oarÄƒ** | var / ve-ri-sho-a-ra | kuzyn / kuzynka |
| **cumnat** | kum-nat | szwagier |
| **cumnatÄƒ** | kum-na-ta | szwagierka |

## Pierwsze spotkanie

<PhraseOfDay
  word="ÃŽncÃ¢ntat de cunoÈ™tinÈ›Äƒ"
  translation="Milo mi poznac"
  pronunciation="en-ken-tat de ku-nosh-tin-tsa"
  context="Formalne powitanie przy pierwszym spotkaniu"
/>

### Powitania

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **BunÄƒ ziua!** | bu-na zi-ua | DzieÅ„ dobry! (formalnie) |
| **ÃŽncÃ¢ntat/Äƒ de cunoÈ™tinÈ›Äƒ** | en-ken-tat/a de ku-nosh-tin-tsa | Milo mi poznac |
| **Am auzit multe despre dumneavoastrÄƒ** | am a-u-zit mul-te des-pre dum-nea-vo-as-tra | DuÅ¼o o Panstwu slyszalem |
| **V-am adus un mic cadou** | vam a-dus un mik ka-dou | Przynioslem maly prezent |

<CultureTip title="Prezenty dla rodziny" flag="ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡´">
W Rumunii wypada przyjsc z prezentem - kwiaty dla pani domu (nieparzysta liczba, nie biale lilije!), wino, czekoladki lub cos z Polski. Rumuni doceniaja gosc, ktory przynosi dary!
</CultureTip>

## Uprzejme zwroty

<VocabCard
  word="SunteÈ›i foarte drÄƒguÈ›i"
  translation="Sa Panstwo bardzo mili"
  pronunciation="sun-tetsi fo-ar-te dra-gutsi"
  example="SunteÈ›i foarte drÄƒguÈ›i, mulÈ›umesc pentru invitaÈ›ie."
/>

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **MulÈ›umesc** | mul-tsu-mesk | Dziekuje |
| **MulÈ›umesc foarte mult** | mul-tsu-mesk fo-ar-te mult | Dziekuje bardzo |
| **VÄƒ rog** | va rog | Prosze |
| **ScuzaÈ›i-mÄƒ** | sku-za-tsi-ma | Przepraszam |
| **ÃŽmi pare rÄƒu** | e-mi pa-re rau | Jest mi przykro |

## Przy stole

<VocabCard
  word="Este delicios!"
  translation="Jest pyszne!"
  pronunciation="es-te de-li-chios"
  example="Sarmalele sunt delicioase!"
/>

### Podstawowe zwroty

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **PoftÄƒ bunÄƒ!** | pof-ta bu-na | Smacznego! |
| **Noroc!** | no-rok | Na zdrowie! (toast) |
| **MulÈ›umesc, ajunge** | mul-tsu-mesk, a-zhun-dje | Dziekuje, wystarczy |
| **Mai vreau puÈ›in** | mai vreau pu-tsin | Poprosze jeszcze troche |
| **MÃ¢ncarea e delicioasÄƒ** | men-ka-rea e de-li-chi-o-a-sa | Jedzenie jest pyszne |

<CultureTip title="Rumunska goscinnosc" flag="ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡´">
Rumuni sÄ… slynni z goscinnosci! Gospodarz bedzie nalegac, Å¼ebys jadl wiÄ™cej - to wyraz troski. Przygotuj siÄ™ na obfite posilki i nie odmawiaj wszystkiego. "Poftim!" (Prosze, czestuj sie!) uslyszysz bardzo czesto!
</CultureTip>

## Rozmowa z rodzina

<PhraseOfDay
  word="De unde este familia dumneavoastrÄƒ?"
  translation="Skad pochodzi Panstwa rodzina?"
  pronunciation="de un-de es-te fa-mi-li-a dum-nea-vo-as-tra"
  context="Dobre pytanie na poczatek rozmowy"
/>

### Pytania i odpowiedzi

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **Unde lucraÈ›i?** | un-de lu-kratsi | Gdzie Panstwo pracuja? |
| **Sunt din Polonia** | sunt din po-lo-ni-a | Jestem z Polski |
| **Da, o iubesc foarte mult** | da, o ju-besk fo-ar-te mult | Tak, bardzo ja kocham |
| **ÃŽnvÄƒÈ› limba romÃ¢nÄƒ** | en-vats lim-ba ro-me-na | Ucze siÄ™ rumunskiego |

### Mowienie o waszym zwiazku

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **Suntem Ã®mpreunÄƒ de un an** | sun-tem em-pre-u-na de un an | Jestesmy razem od roku |
| **Ne-am cunoscut Ã®n BucureÈ™ti** | ne-am ku-nos-kut en bu-ku-reshti | Poznalismy siÄ™ w Bukareszcie |
| **Sunt foarte fericit/Äƒ cu el/ea** | sunt fo-ar-te fe-ri-chit/a ku el/ea | Jestem z nim/nia bardzo szczesliwy/a |

## Tradycje rodzinne

<VocabCard
  word="Ce tradiÈ›ii aveÈ›i Ã®n familie?"
  translation="Jakie macie tradycje rodzinne?"
  pronunciation="che tra-di-tsii a-vetsi en fa-mi-li-e"
  example="Mi-ar plÄƒcea sÄƒ cunosc tradiÈ›iile voastre."
/>

### Rumunskie swieta

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **CrÄƒciun** | kra-chiun | Boze Narodzenie |
| **PaÈ™te** | pash-te | Wielkanoc |
| **ziua de naÈ™tere** | zi-ua de nash-te-re | urodziny |
| **ziua onomasticÄƒ** | zi-ua o-no-mas-ti-ka | imieniny |
| **Revelion** | re-ve-li-on | Sylwester |

<CultureTip title="Wielkanoc w Rumunii" flag="ðŸ‡·ðŸ‡´">
Wielkanoc (PaÈ™tele) to najwaÅ¼niejsze swieto w Rumunii. O polnocy wszyscy ida do cerkwi Å¼e swiecami, a nastepnie biora udzial w uczcie z "cozonac" (ciasto), "drob" (pasztet wielkanocny) i malowanymi jajkami.
</CultureTip>

## Pozegnanie

<VocabCard
  word="MulÈ›umesc pentru invitaÈ›ie"
  translation="Dziekuje za zaproszenie"
  pronunciation="mul-tsu-mesk pen-tru in-vi-ta-tsi-e"
  example="MulÈ›umesc pentru invitaÈ›ie, a fost minunat."
/>

| Rumunski | Wymowa | Polski |
|----------|--------|--------|
| **M-am simÈ›it foarte bine** | mam sim-tsit fo-ar-te bi-ne | Bardzo dobrze siÄ™ bawilem |
| **Sper sÄƒ ne revedem curÃ¢nd** | sper sÄ… ne re-ve-dem ku-rend | Mam nadzieje, Å¼e wkrÃ³tce siÄ™ zobaczymy |
| **SÄƒ aveÈ›i grijÄƒ de dumneavoastrÄƒ** | sÄ… a-vetsi gri-zha de dum-nea-vo-as-tra | Niech siÄ™ Panstwo o siebie troszcza |
| **La revedere!** | la re-ve-de-re | Do widzenia! |

## Wskazowki kulturowe

### Co robic:
- Przyniesc prezent dla gospodarzy
- Komplementowac jedzenie i dom
- Okazywac zainteresowanie rodzina
- Uzywac formalnych zwrotow na poczatku
- Przyjac druga porcje jedzenia
- Proponowac pomoc przy sprzataniu

### Czego unikac:
- Odmawiac jedzenia lub picia
- Przychodzic z pustymi rekami
- Uzywac "tu" zbyt szybko
- Krytykowania czegokolwiek
- Zostawiac jedzenie na talerzu

## Ä†wiczenia przygotowawcze

### Scenka: Powitanie
Przecwiczcie formalne powitanie z partnerem:
- **"BunÄƒ ziua! ÃŽncÃ¢ntat de cunoÈ™tinÈ›Äƒ."**
- **"V-am adus ceva din Polonia."**

### Opowiadanie o sobie
Przygotujcie krotka prezentacje po rumunsku:
- Skad jestes
- Czym siÄ™ zajmujesz
- Jak poznales/as partnera

### Komplementy
Naucz siÄ™ kilku komplementow na pamiec:
- **"AveÈ›i o casÄƒ foarte frumoasÄƒ"** (Macie bardzo piÄ™kny dom)
- **"MÃ¢ncarea e delicioasÄƒ"** (Jedzenie jest pyszne)
- **"SunteÈ›i o familie minunatÄƒ"** (Jestescie wspaniala rodzina)

## Podsumowanie

Spotkanie z rumunska rodzina partnera to szansa na pokazanie szacunku i zainteresowania kultura. Rumuni sÄ… bardzo goÅ›cinni i ciepli - nawet podstawowa znajomosc jÄ™zyka zrobi ogromne wrazenie!

## Kontynuuj nauke

- **[Rumunskie powitania](/learn/pl/ro/romanian-greetings-farewells/)** - CodzieÅ„ne zwroty
- **[Zwroty dla par](/learn/pl/ro/romanian-essential-phrases-for-couples/)** - Podstawowa komunikacja
- **[Slownictwo na randke](/learn/pl/ro/romanian-date-night-vocabulary/)** - Romantyczne sÅ‚ownictwo
- **[Podstawy gramatyki](/learn/pl/ro/romanian-grammar-basics/)** - Zrozum strukture

<CTA text="Gotowi na spotkanie z rumunska rodzina?" buttonText="Zacznij teraz" />

articles.title: Spanish Shopping Vocabulary for Couples
articles.content:
import VocabCard from '@components/VocabCard.astro';
import ConjugationTable from '@components/ConjugationTable.astro';
import CultureTip from '@components/CultureTip.astro';
import PhraseOfDay from '@components/PhraseOfDay.astro';
import CTA from '@components/CTA.astro';

Shopping together as a couple is one of life's simple pleasures, whether you're browsing local markets for souvenirs, picking out gifts for each other, or exploring fashion boutiques in a Spanish-speaking city. Knowing the right vocabulary transforms a potentially frustrating experience into an enjoyable adventure.

Learning shopping Spanish together means you can help each other navigate stores, bargain at markets, and find exactly what you're looking for without stress.

## Entering a Store

### Greetings and First Phrases

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Buenas tardes | Good afternoon |
| Solo estamos mirando | We're just looking |
| Â¿Nos puede ayudar? | Can you help us? |
| Busco... | I'm looking for... |
| Buscamos... | We're looking for... |
| Â¿DÃ³nde puedo encontrar...? | Where can I find...? |
| Â¿Tienen...? | Do you have...? |

<VocabCard
  word="Solo estamos mirando"
  translation="We're just looking"
  pronunciation="[SOH-loh ehs-TAH-mohs mee-RAHN-doh]"
  example="Gracias, solo estamos mirando por ahora."
/>

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Â¿Me lo puedo probar?"
  translation="Can I try it on?"
  pronunciation="[meh loh PWEH-doh proh-BAHR]"
  context="Essential phrase for trying on clothes or accessories"
/>

## Clothing (La Ropa)

### Basic Clothing Items

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| la camisa | shirt |
| la camiseta | t-shirt |
| los pantalones | pants |
| los jeans / los vaqueros | jeans |
| el vestido | dress |
| la falda | skirt |
| el suÃ©ter | sweater |
| la chaqueta | jacket |
| el abrigo | coat |
| los shorts | shorts |

### More Clothing

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| la blusa | blouse |
| el traje | suit |
| la corbata | tie |
| el cinturÃ³n | belt |
| los calcetines | socks |
| la ropa interior | underwear |
| el pijama | pajamas |
| el baÃ±ador / traje de baÃ±o | swimsuit |

<VocabCard
  word="el vestido"
  translation="the dress"
  pronunciation="[ehl behs-TEE-doh]"
  example="Ese vestido te queda perfecto, mi amor."
/>

### Accessories (Los Accesorios)

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| los zapatos | shoes |
| las zapatillas | sneakers |
| las botas | boots |
| las sandalias | sandals |
| los tacones | heels |
| el bolso / la bolsa | bag/purse |
| el sombrero | hat |
| la gorra | cap |
| el reloj | watch |
| las gafas de sol | sunglasses |
| la bufanda | scarf |
| los guantes | gloves |

<CultureTip title="Shopping Hours" flag="ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸">
In Spain, many stores close for siesta (around 2-5 PM) and stay open until 8-9 PM. On Sundays, most stores are closed except in tourist areas. In Latin America, hours vary more but Sunday shopping is common in malls. Always check "horario" (hours) before heading out!
</CultureTip>

## Sizes and Fit

### Asking About Size

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Â¿QuÃ© talla usas? | What size do you wear? |
| Â¿QuÃ© nÃºmero calzas? | What shoe size do you wear? |
| Â¿Tiene una talla mÃ¡s grande? | Do you have a larger size? |
| Â¿Tiene una talla mÃ¡s pequeÃ±a? | Do you have a smaller size? |
| Â¿Tiene esto en otro color? | Do you have this in another color? |
| No tenemos su talla | We don't have your size |

<VocabCard
  word="Â¿QuÃ© talla usas?"
  translation="What size do you wear?"
  pronunciation="[keh TAH-yah OO-sahs]"
  example="Amor, Â¿quÃ© talla usas? Te quiero comprar algo."
/>

### Size Terms

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| pequeÃ±o/a (P) | small (S) |
| mediano/a (M) | medium (M) |
| grande (G) | large (L) |
| extra grande (XG) | extra large (XL) |
| talla Ãºnica | one size |
| la talla | clothing size |
| el nÃºmero | shoe size |

### Describing Fit

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Me queda bien | It fits me well |
| Me queda grande | It's too big on me |
| Me queda pequeÃ±o/apretado | It's too small/tight |
| Te queda perfecto | It looks perfect on you |
| Me queda largo/corto | It's too long/short |
| Â¿CÃ³mo me queda? | How does it look on me? |

<PhraseOfDay
  word="Te queda muy bien"
  translation="It looks great on you"
  pronunciation="[teh KEH-dah mwee bee-EHN]"
  context="The perfect compliment when your partner tries something on"
/>

## Colors (Los Colores)

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| negro/a | black |
| blanco/a | white |
| rojo/a | red |
| azul | blue |
| verde | green |
| amarillo/a | yellow |
| naranja / anaranjado | orange |
| rosa / rosado | pink |
| morado / pÃºrpura | purple |
| marrÃ³n / cafÃ© | brown |
| gris | gray |
| beige | beige |
| dorado | gold |
| plateado | silver |

<VocabCard
  word="Â¿Lo tienen en otro color?"
  translation="Do you have it in another color?"
  pronunciation="[loh tee-EH-nehn ehn OH-troh koh-LOR]"
  example="Me gusta este diseÃ±o. Â¿Lo tienen en azul?"
/>

## Paying and Prices

### Asking About Price

| Spanish | English |
|---------|---------|
| Â¿CuÃ¡nto cuesta? | How much does it cost? |
| Â¿CuÃ¡nto es? | How much is it? |
| Â¿CuÃ¡l es el precio? | What's the price? |
| Â¿Tiene descuento? | Is there a discount? |

<CultureTip title="Bargaining Culture" flag="ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸">
Bargaining is common in markets (mercados) throughout Latin America and some parts of Spain. In regular stores, prices are fixed. At markets, try "Â¿Me hace un descuento?" (Can you give me a discount?) or "Â¿CuÃ¡l es su mejor precio?" (What's your best price?). Be friendly and respectful - it's a social exchange!
</CultureTip>

<CultureTip title="El Corte InglÃ©s" flag="ðŸ‡ªðŸ‡¸">
If you're in Spain, "El Corte InglÃ©s" is the famous department store chain found in most cities. It's a great place to shop because staff often speak English, and you can find everything from clothing to electronics to gourmet food under one roof.
</CultureTip>

## Practice Dialogue: Shopping for a Gift

**Shop assistant:** Buenas tardes, Â¿les puedo ayudar en algo?

**You:** SÃ­, buscamos un regalo para mi suegra.

**Partner:** Algo especial, como una bufanda o un bolso.

**Shop assistant:** Tenemos unas bufandas de seda muy bonitas. Â¿De quÃ© color buscan?

**You:** Â¿QuÃ© te parece azul, amor? Le gusta el azul.

**Partner:** SÃ­, perfecto. Â¿Nos muestra las azules?

**Shop assistant:** Claro, aquÃ­ tienen. Esta es de seda pura, hecha a mano.

**You:** Â¡QuÃ© bonita! Â¿CuÃ¡nto cuesta?

**Shop assistant:** EstÃ¡ a 45 euros, pero hoy tenemos un 20% de descuento.

**Partner:** Entonces queda en 36 euros, Â¿verdad?

**Shop assistant:** Exacto. Â¿Se la llevo a caja?

**You:** SÃ­, por favor. Y si tiene una bolsita de regalo...

## Make Shopping an Adventure

Shopping in Spanish-speaking countries is about more than just buying things - it's a cultural experience. From chatting with friendly vendors at local markets to exploring elegant boutiques, speaking Spanish opens doors and creates memorable moments together.

Remember to be patient with yourselves, have fun practicing these phrases, and enjoy the adventure of discovering new places and treasures as a couple!
